Growing up in the Marcy Houses, a notorious housing project, Jay-Z faced numerous challenges.

Despite the obstacles, he learned to harness his environment to fuel his art. His first foray into the world of hip-hop was through freestyling on streets, using his experiences as fodder for his lyrics. This raw talent caught the attention of several music industry figures, leading to his signing with the legendary record label Def Jam Records in 1996.

His debut album, Reasonable Doubt (1996), immediately solidified his position as one of the most prominent figures in the hip-hop scene. His following albums, such as The Infamous (1999) and The Blueprint (2001), demonstrated his growing popularity and solidified his reputation as an exceptional lyricist, as well as a talented record producer.

Beyond his accomplishments in music, Jay-Z has made a significant impact on business and social activism. He founded the Roc-A-Fella Records label, and later, he co-founded the Def Jam Recordings group and the streaming platform Tidal. In 2011, he became the CEO of Def Jam Recordings and entered into a joint venture with Samsung to create a luxury division, Rocawear.

Apart from his business ventures, Jay-Z has also made notable contributions to philanthropy. In 2013, he created the Shawn Carter Foundation, which supports youth in communities across the United States. In 2018, he established the Jay-Z Opportunity Fund to provide access to capital for Black-owned businesses.
